content: How can I help you today?

I've just been really struggling to sleep because of all this stress from work. It’s hard to shut my brain off at night, and I end up scrolling on my phone, which I know doesn’t help. My partner suggested I talk to someone, but honestly, I’m not sure how much this can really help.

It sounds like work stress has been weighing on you, making it difficult to relax and get the rest you need. That's not easy to deal with, especially when it feels like your mind won't shut off. Taking that step to talk about it shows a lot of openness, even if you're uncertain right now about how helpful it might be. What do you think might make handling this stress feel a little easier for you?

I guess just figuring out a way to calm my mind at night would help, but I don't even know where to start. The stress just feels constant, and once I’m in bed, all I can think about is work and what will happen if I lose my job. It’s like my brain won’t let me rest, no matter what I do.

It sounds like your stress about work and the fear of losing your job are really dominating your thoughts, especially at night when things are quieter and there's more space to think. That's an exhausting place to be, and it makes sense that it feels hard to know where to start. You're wanting relief from this constant cycle—that desire to calm your mind is an important thing to focus on. What has helped you get even a little bit of peace or relaxation in the past, if anything?

Honestly, I haven’t really found much that works. I usually just end up distracting myself with my phone until I get too tired. But even then, I feel like I’m not actually relaxing, and it just makes everything worse. I just don’t know how to slow my thoughts down.

It sounds like you're trying what you can to cope, but scrolling on your phone doesn’t feel like it’s giving you the relief you’re looking for—it’s more like a way to push through the moment without feeling better. Slowing down those racing thoughts seems really tough right now, but the fact that you're thinking about it and noticing what doesn’t work is a positive step. What do you wish your nights felt like, if you could picture something different?

I think I’d just want to go to bed peacefully, without my brain running a million miles an hour. Like, I’d want to feel calm and not wake up feeling even more tired than when I went to bed. I just wish I had that quiet moment, you know?

That longing for a peaceful end to the day, a quiet moment where your mind isn’t racing, sounds so reasonable. It’s clear how much you value calm and rest, especially when your nights leave you drained instead of refreshed. Stress seems to crowd out that calm you’re yearning for. What do you think it would take to help create that quiet space for yourself, even just a little bit?

I’m not sure, honestly. Everything just feels so overwhelming that I don’t even know what could actually work. Maybe if I could find some way to stop thinking about work, but it feels impossible to let it go when it’s all so uncertain.

It sounds like the uncertainty around work is at the center of your stress, making it hard to set those thoughts aside and let go, even for a short time. When something feels uncertain, it can consume all your energy, leaving you overwhelmed and unsure of what to try next. But even in the face of this, you've shown insight—you recognize that focusing on work is part of the challenge. What would letting go of work, even for a short time at night, mean for you?

I think letting go of work, even for just a bit, would mean I could finally breathe and have some relief from all the pressure. It’s just hard because I feel like if I’m not worrying about it, I’m not doing enough to fix it or be prepared. But I know I can’t keep this up without burning out completely.

It sounds like you’re carrying so much responsibility and pressure, as if worrying is the only way to stay on top of everything. At the same time, you recognize that this constant stress could lead to burnout, and you’re craving that space to breathe and experience relief. Balancing your concerns and preparing yourself while also finding moments of true rest feels like the challenge here. What do you think would need to change for you to allow yourself even a small bit of relief without feeling guilty about it?

I think I'd have to really believe that taking care of myself isn’t selfish, and that it might actually help me handle everything a little better. It’s hard, though, because I feel like if I let go for even a moment, something might fall apart. It’s a bit of a cycle I can’t seem to break.

Believing that taking care of yourself isn’t selfish—that it’s actually a way to be stronger and more capable—sounds like a shift that could bring a lot of relief. Right now, it seems like the fear of things falling apart if you pause is keeping you stuck in that cycle, even while you see the toll it’s taking. Recognizing that this cycle exists is a big step forward. How would it feel to take just a small step toward breaking it, one that doesn’t feel overwhelming?

It would honestly feel like a relief to start breaking the cycle, even if it’s just step by step. But I’d still worry about whether I’m doing enough or if I’m letting things slip. I guess if it were just a small step, it might feel more manageable. Do you have ideas for what that could look like?

Thank you for sharing that taking small steps feels more manageable—it’s clear you’re ready to start exploring ways to break this cycle. Before moving forward, is there anything else on your mind about this situation or about what’s been weighing on you? Let’s make sure we focus on everything that’s important to you before thinking about ideas together.

I think most of it comes back to the stress about work and being worried I’m not doing enough to provide for my family. It’s hard to feel like I’m juggling everything well, and it’s tough to feel like I’m falling short, even though I’m trying so hard. I want to be a good partner and parent, but the stress makes me feel less present with my family too. Everything just feels like a lot right now.

It sounds like you care deeply about doing your best for your family and being a supportive partner and parent, which is why the pressure feels so heavy. Balancing work stress and family life, while trying to provide and stay present, is pulling you in so many directions, and it’s understandable that this all feels overwhelming. Your commitment to your family and to finding relief shows such strength, even when things feel so hard. Is there anything else you’d like to talk about before thinking about first steps together?

I think that’s most of it, honestly. I just wish I could feel like I was handling things better and not letting the stress take over so much. Let’s talk about those small steps—I feel like I need something to start with, even if I’m not sure it’ll work.

Thank you for sharing everything that’s been on your mind—it’s clear how much effort you’re putting in, even when carrying so much stress. It sounds like you’re ready to explore some manageable steps forward.  

To summarize everything important you’ve shared: you’re dealing with significant stress about work and providing for your family, and that’s affecting your sleep, sense of calm, and presence with your loved ones. You’re yearning for a way to break the cycle gradually, so you can feel more relief and balance without letting the stress dictate your life.  

Would it be okay to talk about ideas for small steps that could help create that balance?
